campaign.story:
Hate to start with a disclaimer, but it feels necessary: In these weird and worthless Corona times there might be unexpected and pandemic-related delays. Hopefully not, but you never know. Be safe friends, and take this virus seriously. With that said:
This is a Kickstarter for a zine full of MÖRK BORG stuff. Most of it is created by our wonderful community, but there are also exclusive, official material. 
 MÖRK BORG is a blackened artpunk doomsday rpg about miserable bastards and heretics enduring a bleak, dying world. It's a doom metal album of a game. A spiked flail to the face. Rules light, heavy everything else. It's made by Pelle Nilsson of Ockult Örtmästare Games and Johan Nohr from Stockholm Kartell, and published by Free League Publishing. Check it out here, you might like it. Some people said this:   
 When we first made MÖRK BORG, we had NO IDEA that 1) a community would form around the game and 2) how crazy creative and imaginative and awesome it would be. But from even before the book was released, people made custom stuff for the game. So we created MÖRK BORG CULT (MBC), a sub-label for selected, approved and curated MÖRK BORG content. Basically, you send us homebrew stuff and if we like it, we make some edits, art and lay it out before publishing it for free download on morkborg.com. We want it dark, cruel, and easy to use but will never accept racist, sexist, homophobic or transphobic content. Digital MBC content will always be free, but now we'd like to (on popular demand) also print it as a neat little zine. Should we manage to fund this, there might be more issues in the future when we get more material. Only Nechrubel knows.
 MÖRK BORG CULT: FERETORY is a collection of tables, monsters, items, classes, rules and ideas that you can use in your MÖRK BORG game, or any other rules light osr-style game about deadly adventures, cursed treasure and terrible odds. All community made content in the zine will eventually be published for free download on morkborg.com, and some already have been. The things done by Pelle and Johan however, will only be available in this zine. The money from this Kickstarter will be spent on printing, editing, proofreading and of course compensating the content creators. 
MÖRK BORG CULT: FERETORY is published by Free League Publishing, same as MÖRK BORG was. They will handle printing, distribution and digital fullfilment. 
To get you in the right mood for this zine, we put together a Spotify playlist. Find it here. (for some weird reason Kickstarter won't allow us to embed it here).
The eyes will be sparkly holographic foil! Don't look directly into them. Or do it, we can't stop you.
 Cursed Skinwalker. A shapeshifting class whose careless drifting in the land of the dead merged its soul with that of another being. By Karl Druid. 
 Pale One. This strange character class is utterly alien, fundamentally other, and belongs no where. Watching, judging, waiting. By Tim Rudloff. 
 Dead God's Prophet. A heretical character class preaching the gospel of a dead god, slain by The Two-Headed Basilisks. But don't tell the church. By Greg Saunders. 
 d100 Items & Trinkets. What can be scored in the darkest of cellars and the rucksacks of the fallen? Use this list of keepsakes and trinkets to find out. By Pelle Svensson. 
 Roads to Damnation. Simple rules for overland travel, including distances, road encounters, village types and destinations. By Svante Landgraf. 
 Eat Prey Kill. Rules for hunting for food (or sport). Also 54 fully statted monsters, 6 for each major area of the dying world. By Karl Druid. 
 The Death Ziggurat. A delve into the ruins of a lost temple city where something is awakening. A descent into undead madness. A Cosmic Necrocrawl at the end of time. The Death Ziggurat is a short adventure about postponing the inevitable. By Carl Niblaeus. 
 The Goblin Grinder. The streets of Galgenbeck are overrun with goblins, turning burgher and pauper alike into their own cursed kin. But not to worry! For a low cost, a local chemist can whip up a cure. Until the price rises anyway. Risks? Of course not, it's tested and guaranteed to work! A cursed urban slaughterfest of an adventure about plagues, panic and profit. By Donovan Caldwell. 
 The Tenebrous Reliquery. A d66 table of terrible treasures. The Volt Thrower and the Plasmatic Idol. The Cauldron of Lies and the Zodiac Lung. Tyrant's Tongue and the Foehammer. By Anders Arpi, Ben H, Dom Cohen, Donny C, Johan Nohr, Karl Druid, Leander Elwischger, Paul Wilde and Flora v/d B. 
These things will NOT be made available as free downloads on morkborg.com, this is the only way to get a hold of them:
 Forlorn Philosopher. A despondent, ever brooding character class aiming to control this world's harrowing fate with the power of overthinking everything. 
 Obscure Ochre Tablets. Ancient, sought-after clay tablets containing Powers that only the most enlightened mystic (or forlorn philosopher) can hope to wield. 
 Stretch Goal: Monster Generator. Create your own terrible foe with this generator. Determine appearance, behavior, abilities, goal and strange habits for your new friend. This will be included if we reach 70 000 SEK.  
 Stretch Goal: Black Sour Salt. This noxious, poisonous and possibly cursed mineral is carried on the winds of the dying world. Spreading disease and demonic disfigurement to any and all who happen to breathe it. This will be included if we reach 90 000 SEK.
 Stretch Goal: The Grey Galth Inn. Welcome to this fine (ish) establishment in the bad part of Galgenbeck where you can eat, drink and hope to multiply your coins with a game of Three Dead Skulls. This will be included if we reach 360 000 SEK.
Pelle's content is of course in English and we will once again be helped by Patrick Stuart, but: Swedish versions of these items will also be included in the MÖRK BORG CULT: FERETORY pdf as an appendix.  
The Cursed Skinwalker. And cursing skinwalker, it seems.
If we manage to get the funds we need to get the MÖRK BORG CULT: FERETORY printed, we're looking at something quite different from what MÖRK BORG is. This is a rough zine, a haphazardly composited collection of ideas and articles, and we want it to feel like something you'd pick up at a concert, or an underground art fair. It'll be a soft-cover zine, about 60-ish A5 pages thick, printed on heavily textured uncoated paper in 6 colors (CMYK+2), with some extra things like holographic foiling and maybe we'll use golden staples, who knows? The goal is to make it easy to carry, easy to use, and as pretty as we can make it. And easy to burn, you never know.
 Pledge levels and what they include
We're not only going to print this fancy zine if we manage to get this Kickstarter funded. If you go for the big ol' limited Cult Leader reward, there are other goodies in store for you. Namely: 
MÖRK BORG FERETORY t-shirt
✖ Printed by Spreadshirt (the same place that makes our Merch Borg tees). This tee will never be printed again after this Kickstarter ends. 
MÖRK BORG stickers
✖ Three of them. They're holographic, mirrored and soft-touch. One you can use to mark character sheets of dead PCs (or anything dead, really). The others can be used to bling-out just about anything. These will be made available for purchase later on. That also goes for:
 Pamphlet dungeon: Death Temple Sztun 
✖ This hyper-linear murder gauntlet of a dungeon crawl first saw the light of day/dark of night at our release party. But now you can get your grubby hands on it even if you weren't there. This is not KS exclusive, but you will have it before everyone else gets a chance!
✖ Also, if you choose this pledge level, your copy of the zine will be signed by Johan and Pelle. Unfortunately.
 Sure are. If we get more than we bargained for, we'll add extra content to the zine. Namely:
70 000 SEK. Monster Generator. Create your own terrible foe with this generator. Determine appearance, behavior, abilities, goal and strange habits for your new friend.
90 000 SEK. Black Sour Salt. This noxious, poisonous and possibly cursed mineral is carried on the winds of the dying world. Spreading disease and demonic disfigurement to any and all who happen to breathe it.
110 000 SEK. We add a cool holographic foil to a random page. Or, not really random, it just felt fun to write that.
225 000 SEK. We add a gold foil to a non-random page. It will be cool as hell.
275 000 SEK. We include the micro/solo catacomb crawling game DARK FORT with every physical copy of the zine. A 4 page A5 mini-zine where you delve into a randomly generated crypt and hope not to die.
Super early mockup of the vibe we're going for with DARK FORT
360 000 SEK. The Grey Galth Inn. Welcome to this fine (ish) establishment in the bad part of Galgenbeck where you can eat, drink and hope to multiply your coins with a game of Three Dead Skulls. 
420 000 SEK. Digital dungeon generator. If we reach this high we will scvmbirthify (that's a real word) the dungeon generator in the back of the rulebook, i.e. create a digital generator app that let's you randomize dungeon ideas and concepts for your game.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
All texts are written and most of the art and layout is done, but we still need to sort out proofreading and editing which could take a while. After that, Free League takes care of printing, shipping and distribution which they have done more than a few times before so the risks are quite low on this one. Our last Kickstarter (For the MÖRK BORG book) went smoothly and the books reached the majority of the backers right on time. 
But then came corona. Despite us making a game about the end of the world we are not big fans of these latest events. At all. It truly sucks. And to be completely honest, we don't know if and/or how this pandemic will affect us. Printing might be delayed, shipping could be crippled. We'll just have to wait and see how things turn out. But all that can be made digitally will be unaffected. So in the worst case you'll get the PDFs before you get the print, even though we would prefer it the other way around.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

We just got word from the printer's that the zines are PRINTED and ready to ship. About 200 are on their way to MÖRK BORG HQ in Stockholm right now and the rest is heading for the UK warehouse for packing and shipping out to backers. We have just ordered a ton of boxes and bubble wrap, for the Cult Leaders' packages (which we pack and ship manually) and the PDF is almost done. Shit's getting real!

Best Writing 
Best Layout and Design 
Best Game (silver, but heyyy) 
Product of the Year

The MÖRK BORG CULT: FERETORY is currently being printed and prepared for shipping, but already now we release some of its content: The Tenebrous Reliquary. https://dngngen.makedatanotlore.dev/

campaign.story:
The Wizard is just that. He wears a pointed hat. Never refer to him as anything else, through description, NPC dialogue, etc. He is the truth.
In the tranquil hamlet of Canny, there's a bounty out on a wizard. Allegedly, he wreaked some havoc before escaping to his Tower on the Hill to the north. As the characters discover the carnage he left behind and begin to explore his sinister lair, it becomes increasingly clear that whatever they're dealing with is definitely not a wizard- but he's somehow convinced everybody else that he is. 
The wizard's bounty.
A 20+ page OSR tabletop module complete with eerie monochrome illustrations by the incomparable Lou. It features: 
The town of Canny, simple and vulnerable
The Tower on the Hill, a five-floor, 25 room dungeon filled with horrid traps, creatures, and secrets
The Wizard, an unknowable, cosmic evi- A man who has magical powers, especially in legends and fairy tales (Oxford). His door is open. There are such wondrous sights beyond.    
We're printing through Mixam. The zine will be 5.5"x8.5", black and white, and printed on 80 lb paper. The cover will be 110 lb paper with a matte finish. 
A page detailing the Tower and its lovely little oddities.
To keep the budget as attainable as possible, these costs purely cover the production and distribution of the zine; nothing else. 
 $225 for printing, shipping, fulfillment, etc - covers a 50 print run. 
 $400 for Lou's uncanny artwork. 
 $40 for the Kickstarter fees.
At $1,200, I can raise Lou's pay as well as pay myself, something that isn't part of the initial budget. [REACHED!]
At $1,700, Johan Nohr (Barkhäxan, MÖRK BORG, Symbaroum) will illustrate the maps for the Tower on the Hill. [REACHED!]
At $2,500, Jonathan Wojcik AKA Bogleech (Awful Hospital, Bogleech.com) will write an optional dungeon accessible through the Tower on the Hill. [REACHED!].
At $3,500, we'll print Johan's maps on posters and send them out to all existing physical backers. [REACHED!]
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This is my first kickstarter, but not my first tabletop game project. I've kept this kickstarter small and manageable in an attempt to both keep costs low and reduce the margin of error. In addition, we have two backups in case we have issues with Mixam: PrintingCenterUSA and a local printing business (Dateline Printing). I have confidence in our ability to deliver the final product.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content: Just a small update to let you guys know that some packages are being sent back for myriad reasons. This isn't entirely unexpected given the situation with the post office in the US, and we're working to make sure all the backers get their packages.

After several unexpected delays, your copies of A Wizard are ready for shipping, and will be on their way either this Friday (August 6), or Monday (August 10)! If you don't receive them within a reasonable timeframe or have any other questions, you can message me here on Kickstarter or Twitter (@Donovanplanet). Thank you sincerely to everyone who helped make this weird module a reality.

We'll be putting labels on packages pretty soon here, so I'm just warning all backers to LOCK IN YOUR ADDRESSES by July 5th! There were a couple delays, but all copies of a Wizard should be shipped before July's over. I'm excited to see everyone get their copies!
A WIZARD IS HERE!!!

After a bit of kerfuffle, all the keys should be in their proper places (you, the backer's emails) now. I am so excited for everyone to read this thing! Over the next couple months, I'll be steadily updating everyone as the zine is printed and distributed. For now, if anyone has any issues with the PDF at all or has any further questions for me, you can DM me on Twitter or email me at donovancaldwell00@gmail.com. Thank you!!!

Using a KS update to let you know, since sending emails to everyone individually is a little fiddly: there's an issue with the download keys. I'm figuring it out and everyone should have their keys shortly. Thanks for your patience!

The PDF is going to be sent out by Monday, the 17th. Phew! All the maps are done, and now it's just time to clean things up and get it in the hands of all of you wonderful backers. And what maps they are! LOOK at this:

Hey everyone! Quick update to let you know how things are going: 
Formatting and art for A Wizard is in full swing - right now it's just finishing things up and putting them into place. We should be done with the PDF by the end of April, but it may be pushed into early to mid-May; the coronavirus has delayed a lot of things, one being our collaborators workflows. We're hard at work making sure this zine is great (and horrifying)!

Quick update today to let you know where we're at: the Kickstarter money has arrived. From here, I can go about paying contributors, finishing the layout, getting a prototype, and making sure everything is ready to eventually send out the zines.
The optional dungeon is going VERY well. I'm extremely excited for everyone to be able to see it. Every new draft I receive, I'm grinning ear to ear.

The campaign's over! We ended up getting $6,790, which, I would say, is a lot more than our initial $665 goal. Wow?? I'm so excited to get this zine into your (our wonderful backers) hands!! I got some stuff back from Bogleech regarding the optional dungeon, and man, it's gonna be good. It's gonna be GOOD. In the future, I'll be posting occasional updates here and on my Twitter (https://twitter.com/Donovanplanet). The Wizard is COMING!

campaign.story:
Draculola: The Kid Monster Game
Thanks, Backers! We did it!
We are funded and then some! The first Draculola project is about to enter our world. May it be the first of many!
Premise
The Draculola game is for anyone—kids or adults, or kids and adults together! Two little girls (Rosie, 8, and Meri, 5) and their dad (Chris, 48; see the video and the  Our Gang section) created the Draculola game. Based on one of her favorite costumes and the story of the world's most infamous vampire, Rosie created Draculola and wrote stories about her. We thought it'd be fun to create a game about this character and her world as a family. So, we did. Here's the premise.
Draculola, a little vampire girl and your friend, wants to make her home, the creepy realm of Zitterstein, a better place. You can help.
You're also a child in that craggy, forested land. Naturally, you’re a monster, too (probably!). As part of a gang of little creatures, you get up to mischief and adventure all over Zitterstein, sometimes during the day (naughty!). You scare and thwart mean people and monsters; set up elaborate pranks; solve mysteries; and explore hidden places such as fog-shrouded vales and Castle Zitterstein’s endless dungeons.
Zitterstein is changing. Draculola is tired of the monsters’ traditions of scaring and hurting people. She doesn’t want to spend her unlife being nasty to nonvampires and stocking her castle's catacombs with beasts as her parents do. With your help, she has plans to bring more cheer to gloomy old Zitterstein. Her parents don’t approve.
Draculola, her bat Kila, and Zort the ghost kitty
Basics
In the Draculola game, two or more players to play kid monsters on adventures. This game is fun for kids and adults, especially families. One player, the Narrator, runs the game, like a referee, and the other players take on the roles of kid monsters. The little ones live in and delve into a spooky and cartoonish realm where magic and meaner monsters are real. They’re not super scary, and they can be silly, but they exist. The game leans toward creative, fun solutions and playfulness. It leans away from violence. Monsters are hard to hurt anyway!
The game is a 32-page B&W saddle-stitched book, which includes the following.
 Draculola and her friends. She and other sample characters are included. A player can play as Draculola or any of her premade pals. Draculola (named after her great, great grandfather) can instead be a character the Narrator uses to incite and guide adventures.
 Zitterstein, Draculola's home. This setting is yours to play in and create further. It also works as a microsetting for other games. Visit the centaur- and snake-haunted Schlangenhügeln. Swim in vision-inducing waters of the Traumsee with the fishfolk there. Wander the Mondwald, where leaves turn silver in moonlight and visitors should be wary of werewolves and faeries while trying to glimpse a unicorn. Climb the Treppenfels from the village of Arkanor to Castle Zitterstein to visit Draculola. You can use Zitterstein as a whole or in parts you place wherever your imagination takes you.
 Critters of Zitterstein. Spooky, hungry, mean, or just out of sorts, the other creatures of Zitterstain can challenge the kid monsters. Save your friends from the mind-controlling brain bats, emotion-altering whiny bugs, or the fearsome grumpus wumpus. Make friends with a lonely ghost or clumsy giant. Free goblins from the influence of a nasty ogre or help a sick dragon find her fire breath again.
 Rules needed to make up characters and adventures, and play them. Along with these rules, you'll only need pencils, paper, glass beads or similar markers, a few six-sided dice, and your imagination.
Zara, the littlest witch, and her snake, Culu
Giving credit where it's due, this game is inspired by other games. Examples include minigames such as Lasers & Feelings, by John Harper, and similar one-page games by Grant Howitt. Other guiding lights come from more great games that allow you to depict kid heroes, such as Bubblegumshoe, Do: Fate of the Flying Temple, Kids on Bikes, and No Thank You, Evil! (No endorsement from the creators of these games is intended or implied.)
The Game
In the Draculola game, most players make and pretend to be kid monster characters. One other player, as the Narrator, does the rest.
Kid Monsters
Several elements define your kid monster character. This character represents you in the game, takes only a few minutes to make, and can be made randomly. Creating characters is easy enough that my 8-year-old daughter made about twenty in a couple hours. The following details show how the character works in the game.
Your qualities—Origin (monster type), Style (personality), and Skill (biggest talent)—are character elements you can bring to bear in the situations you face.
You also use two traits—Kid and Monster—to accomplish tasks when you need to roll dice. Kid is for doing childlike activities, such as climbing trees, sneaking around, escaping scary things, and eavesdropping on adults and monsters (although some adults are both). Monster is for being scary, using your supernatural powers, and accomplishing tasks most kids couldn't.
When you roll, the number of dice you use depends on the qualities you can use and whether you have an advantage or a disadvantage. Any die that shows a result equal to or lower than the trait you're using—Kid or Monster—succeeds. The number of dice that succeed determines your level of success.
Your Power and Hope help you in the game. You can spend Power to change things in the game and use supernatural abilities more often. Kid monsters are tough, so your Hope determines how long you can keep struggling in a stressful scene. (A scene is one event or encounter in the game, but they're not all stressful.)
You have those aforementioned supernatural abilities, a personal difficulty (we all have them), and favorite objects or pets.
Preview
See how to make your character concept here.
For dicey situations
The Narrator
The Narrator referees the game. They create adventures, set the scenes during play, act the parts of nonplayer characters, and decide when players need to roll. 
Narrators have Power, too. They can use it to make a challenge harder, make a character's personal difficulty important to a scene (encouraging friends to help out), or otherwise change the world. Players who agree to the additional challenge are awarded the Power the Narrator wants to spend.
Stretch Goals
As the campaign funds and exceeds its funding, we'll add more to the zine. If you like what's here and want more, spread the word!
At $4,000 (€3,650), we’ll add 8 more pages for all backers. These pages expand on Zitterstein and the critters and people, some naughty and some nice, that inhabit the land. We'll expand the adventure generator and sample adventures, too. Having more pages also means more art!
At $5,000 (€4,550), we’ll add 8 more pages for all backers. This expansion holds more material like that of the previous goal. Some of this new stuff focuses on using the Draculola characters and setting in other cool games. We'll also be able to hire more help to make the book even nicer.
At $6,000 (€5,550), we'll add an art book to the project. This short tome collects the art in the zine into a shorter book of similar dimensions. It also includes sketches used for preliminary character design. Some of these images can be used to represent characters while playing the game.
At $7,000 (€6,420), we'll add print-and-play cards to the PDF. These cards aid character creation (draw randomly!) and can function as a three-part character sheet.
At $8,000 (€7,325) or more, who knows what we'll add!? Right now, we're considering adventure-creation cards, play without a Narrator, more character and pet art representations, translation into German, and so on.
Onér, a dullahan, knows about stretching... and fire!
Fulfillment
This section presents fulfillment details for the campaign's parts, as well as some transparency on why things cost what they do.
Publications
PDFs. For tiers other than Watcher (no zine), PDFs will be fulfilled through DrivethruRPG and itch.io. You can choose one or both. We're delivering through these sites so you have access to the PDF as part of an independent online library. Besides, itch.io is a good platform for providing copies for people who don't have the financial means to access the game. Chris will provide these community copies on itch.io after the campaign and depending on its success.
Print-on-Demand Zines. For tiers other than Spirit and Watcher, we’re relying on DrivethruRPG to print the zines on demand. Once the booklet is complete, you'll receive a link to order the physical copy at DrivethruRPG’s cost. That’s between $4 (32 pages) and $5 (48 pages) per saddle-stitched book. (Prices slightly lower in Euros.) Shipping is extra, depending on where you live (see this information). The added pledge price is our profit on the physical book to help this campaign fund.
We'll also have a cheaper (about $2.50) perfect-binding option and a more expensive hardcover (about $6.50) option. However, these aren't official Zine Quest 2 bindings. 
See the Plans, Risks, & Challenges section below if you want to know more about why we chose printing and shipping through DrivethruRPG.
Extra Copies
You can buy extra copies of the PDF or PoD zine during the campaign. Here's how. 
Select "Manage your pledge" on this page.
Use "Change your pledge" on the next page. 
Increase the amount for extras you want: $8.50 (€8) per extra PDF, $12 (€11) for PDF and print book, or $3.50 (€3) per extra printed book. S
Send Chris a message through Kickstarter about your increased pledge.
You'll be able to purchase these publications after the campaign through DrivethruRPG or itch.io, but they'll be priced higher than on this Kickstarter. We'd rather any extras help fund the campaign first.
Zine mockup (not final art or design)
Personalized Stuff
Personalized Zines. At the Faeries and Narrator tiers, Rosie, Meri, and Chris will create stuff for you. The family will order a copy of the zine for you, personalize it with autographs dedicated to you, make you four Draculola game characters, and draw those characters. Then, we’ll ship the personalized stuff to you at no extra cost. (You'll still have the option to order a non-personalized zine directly from DrivethruRPG, and if you do, you'll pay shipping on that.) A little of the extra cost for this tier goes to acquiring and shipping the personal stuff to you, but most of it pays for the family's time and creativity. In the end, you’ll have the PDF, one normal zine copy (if you order one), and one personalized copy with your characters and drawings. If you want drawings like those in the book, see Art Add-Ons below.
Bardic Contributions. Added by request on 2/27, the Bard tier provides everything the Faeries tier does. We'll ask you to work with us to create one character, one critter or villain, and one place. (That's three items.) These creations will become part of Zitterstein forever. They'll be in the book. Because of that, we'll want to help mold your ideas to fit the intent and themes in the game. Ultimately, we'll retain the rights to this content, and to change it and use it in future Draculola material. You'll receive credit. of course.
Personalized Adventure. At the Narrator tier, Rosie, Meri, and Chris will create a Draculola adventure for you, using locations and creatures in Zitterstein. Chris will run it for you online. (We'll work out the logistics and other details of doing so after the campaign ends.) A copy of the adventure will come along with your personalized zine. The extra cost is partly for materials, but it's mostly for the many hours the family will spend creating for and playing with you.
Art Add-Ons: After the campaign, Emma (our illustrator) will offer art such as that appearing in the game. You'll be able to get copies of characters from the game or unique illustrations related to the game. A future update will detail how to acquire this art. We're not adding it to the overall campaign so we can meet our basic expenses first.
Our Gang
This section is about the little gang of monsters working on this game.
Chris, Emma, Roselynn, Meridith, and Cal
Chris S. Sims. A veteran game designer and writer, Chris has worked on Dungeons & Dragons, Starfinder, Pathfinder, and other games and films. He's also a graphic artist, so he’ll handle the layout. You can learn more about Chris and his work on his website. You can also follow him on Twitter and get sneak peeks of his work on Patreon.
Roselynn and Meridith Sims. These two are Chris's daughters. For stories she has written and is writing, Rosie (8) came up with Draculola and her home, Zitterstein. We worked together to make up more about this vampire girl and her world. Meri added a few characters of her own, such as Draculola's little brothers, Max and Angelo. The girls posed as reference for some of the illustrations that appear in this book and on this page. Maybe it could go without saying, but these little girls will receive proper credit and compensation as part of this project.
Emma Welch. Emma is a great illustrator just a year or so out of the same art school Chris attended decades ago. Full transparency, she’s also Chris's cousin. Her style is perfect for this project, as you can see on this page. You can follow Emma on Twitter.
Cal Moore. Another gaming veteran, Cal is a fantastic editor (and one of Chris's mentors). He has worked on all sorts of projects as a writer or an editor. Cal has a diverse pool of work, from trading-card games and Dungeons & Dragons for Wizards of the Coast to 13th Age and Shadowrun: Crossfire for Fire Opal Media.
Budget
Chris oversees this project and prefers to pay decent rates, at least for the game industry. For the 32-page game zine, the approximately $3,000 (€2,750) plan includes the following.
 Writing and Editing. $1,800—that's $0.10 per word for writing (for the Simses), $0.06 per word for editing (for Cal).
 Art. $550—Chris buys limited rights. Emma retains her copyrights.
 Fees. $350—Kickstarter and payment fees for Austria.
 Design and Layout. $300—Chris does the layout.
This estimate has a little padding for the unexpected and for fulfilling higher tiers.
As we fund and meet stretch goals, our gang will get paid more. Obviously, extra work will need to be done. However, if we fund higher than needed, every collaborator will share the success with a pay increase. We might hire additional team members to make the product even better.
Ye olde drawing board
Plans, Risks, and Challenges
Let's go over where this project is, why we can make it, and where we're going. If you have any questions, contact us!
The meat of the game is done, as is some of the art.  We’ll keep you posted with previews and updates while the campaign runs and after it funds. (Chris loves sharing sketches and final art.) Once the project is funded, we’ll need time to wrap up with the following.
Writing to final page count
Editing and art direction
Sharing text with product-tier backers for feedback 
Completing art to final page count
Laying out the final book
Fulfilling the zines for backers
Finishing and shipping personalized products
Delivery dates are conservative to make sure you receive the game on time. We'd rather ship early than disappoint.
Chris knows what goes into making a book like this. He's a longtime developer of tabletop roleplaying games and a graphic artist who has been an art director. The team is lined up and ready to go.
This Kickstarter is the first Chris has run. Although he has been behind the scenes in a couple other campaigns, Chris has kept this first campaign small and simple to assure the project gets done right. He's using DrivethruRPG for print fulfillment, because he wants anyone anywhere to be able to get a printed zine without hassle.
Chris lives in Austria. That’s another reason he's using DrivethruRPG fulfillment. Shipping from Austria to elsewhere in the world can be very expensive. The costs per backer would break down approximately as follows. 
 Printing and Handling. $4.50 (€4) 
 Shipping to the EU. $5.50- $6.50 (€5-6)
 Shipping Internationally. $10-16.50 (€9-15)
The total ends up being close to the DrivethruRPG price in most cases. Considering possible unexpected fees, such as customs, the region-based printing and shipping Drivethru offers is lower risk. It's likely to be lower in environmental impact, as well.
Zine Quest 2
This book is part of Kickstarter's Zine Quest 2 month. This format dictates the physical qualities of the book. It also says we can run for only 2 weeks. If you like this little project, help us fund by telling your friends and followers!
We support Kickstarter staff who have successfully formed a union! (See pinned tweet!)

campaign.story:
The Bone Age is an old-school RPG of neolithic-era tribes struggling against the sudden arrival of bug-eyed aliens. You play a Tuzanian, a tribe of jungle-dwelling, vine-swinging, pterodactyl-riding, bone-wielding savages. Radiation leaked from the Invaders' crashed flying saucers spreads on winds of purple, blue, and white, mutating the land and its inhabitants. Meanwhile, a race of turtle-apes and ape-turtles sleeping in stasis beneath the surface awoke...1,000,000 years later than planned. And they were not impressed by the native population – or the alien Invaders.
 The Bone Age will be a 48+ page saddled stitched book with illustrations by the incomparable Jack Woiak.
The Bone Age isn't based on a specific OSR system, but comparisons can be drawn to Swords & Wizardry, Labyrinth Lord, Lamentations of the Flame Princess, and Dungeon Crawl Classics. The base mechanic uses a d20 where higher rolls are better than low rolls, and works in a similar fashion to the way saving throws and attacks work in Labyrinth Lord. Thus, an ability might be expressed as 12+, meaning you want to roll a 12 or higher on a d20. Placing the target number in the hands of the players means they get the thrill of shouting "My attack hits!" or the agony of lamenting "I failed my mutation roll," as opposed to the Game Master setting a secret Difficulty Class.
The Bone Age uses a class & level system, with levels maxing out at 10. The classes you can play are:
 Beast Stalker: hunters of beasts great and small, and the first to encounter the Invaders.
 Marrow Warrior: sentries placed around the perimeter of the Zangatur Jungle, known for their use of the Cleaver, a weapon of serrated bone.
 Mutant: tribe members who developed bizarre mutations after being caught in the radiation winds.
 Untouchable: men and women who tried – and failed – to challenge their chieftain for rulership of the tribe. They are outcasts, surviving on their own in the deadly jungles.
 Wing Rider: riders of massive flying beasts, whether reptilian, avian, or insectoid in nature.
While most of game mechanics in The Bone Age will seem familiar, there are some things that stand out in contrast to many other games. The most important is the concept of Attunement. The land of The Bone Age – called Kalsentia – is itself a living entity, and the creatures that inhabit it can develop a spiritual connection to various geographic regions. These regions are represented by hexes on a map. If you are attuned to a hex, you function more effectively in it. You can attempt to attune to new regions, but you risk the wrath of the land if you offend it – rock slides, earthquakes, and floods are just some of the signs that you have angered Kalsentia.
A map of Kalsentia, the Fevered Continent
 I don't want to give away all its secrets, but here is a taste of some of the things you will discover in The Bone Age:
The land is brutally hot. The north is dry, the south is humid. Many regions see rain only once per solar cycle.
With the exception of the PCs and NPCs, The Bone Age harbors no terran life forms; no horses, no dogs, no bumblebees, no bats, no platypuses.
 The methods necessary to create metal have not been discovered.
The bones of ancient creatures litter the landscape. Bone is thus a resource used for a variety of tools, including weapons.
Three alien ships crashed on the planet one solar cycle ago. Radiation leaks from those ships continues to be carried by the wind, infecting the land and its inhabitants with horrible mutations. The aliens are collectively called the Invaders. 
Advanced technology has been pilfered from Invader ships and Invader dead. Wise men and women have attempted to understand the strange items, to varying degrees of success. Player-characters will discover Invader tech in various states of repair. The use of these items can be unpredictable, wondrous, and dangerous.
 But of course! 
Yep!
UNLOCKED! $2000:  I will write a 16-page adventure. Anyone backing the $16 tier or higher will receive it as a PDF with a link for an at-cost POD.
UNLOCKED! $3000: I will create a 12-16 page GM Toolkit, featuring ideas and tables for enhancing your game and making sure you are able to best portray The Bone Age in all its weirdness. Anyone backing the $16 tier or higher will receive it as a PDF with a link for an at-cost POD.
UNLOCKED! $4000: I will add a second culture along with new classes!

$6000: A second 16-page adventure in pdf and at-cost POD will be created. The adventure can be used as a sequel to the first adventure or used on its own.

campaign.story:
Gradient Descent is a sprawling sci-fi megadungeon for the ENnie award winning Mothership Sci-Fi Horror RPG set in an abandoned android production factory run by a powerful AI. 
The factory, known as the Cloudbank Synthetics Production Facility, may be abandoned, but it's far from uninhabited. Its cramped corridors and dark chambers are populated with androids designed by ASAMM to be so advanced that they are often indistinguishable from humans. Because of this, the factory has been blockaded by a fleet of volunteer corporate vessels who have instructions to kill anything that enters or leaves Cloudbank, otherwise known as: The Deep.
Every NPC you encounter is a potential friend or foe and smart players will survive by relying on their wits over their weapons. You can't shoot your way out of The Deep.
The Cloudbank was coined The Deep by a community of scavengers who camp on the outskirts of the blockade. They call themselves Divers, and their fascination with the strange androids and creations found inside The Deep keeps them coming back. Sometimes to their own detriment. More than one diver has fallen prey to the Bends, a terrible condition where due to the continuous exposure to The Deep's mysteries the Diver forgets whether they are human or not and abandons their friends and loved ones to live in The Deep for the rest of their lives as the android they truly believe they are. That's why the Divers have a saying, "No matter what they say, you never leave anyone behind in The Deep." 
No matter what it looks like, everything in The Deep thinks it's human.
In a lot of ways, Gradient Descent is a love letter to the classic megadungeon from fantasy rpgs, movies like Blade Runner, and comics like Blame!. We've done everything we can to make this massive, sprawling facility with all its nooks and crannies a fun place to explore for players, and an easy game to run for Wardens.
Gradient Descent packs a ton of content into its humble zine-sized pages, including: 
 Hundreds of rooms to explore: Gradient Descent is built from the ground up to be a megadungeon zone that players can return to over many sessions or an entire campaign. They can make quick dives in to scavenge for artifacts, or they can setup camp with the Divers and try and figure out just exactly what's going on down there.
 Hordes of Ghosts: The Deep is ultimately a machine. A very complex, godlike machine, but a machine none the less. And inside this machine are ghosts, echoes and reverberations of brainscans taken by the AI in order to build its sentient androids. Players can't kill them, they'll need to be more thoughtful when they approach these beings.
 Dozens of unique artifacts: You can make it rich in The Deep if you're a little smart, a little crazy, and very lucky. Gradient Descent comes with dozens of unique artifacts to serve as rewards or objectives for Wardens to place all around The Deep.
 A host of factions: The Deep is crammed with different interests. From the Divers, obsessed humans (?) who plumb the depths of The Deep searching for rare android crafted artifacts, to the various communities of androids all living in fear of their AI overlord, or else, the kill teams and Divers who regularly invade their besieged home.
And much, much more!
We've spent a ton of time working this module to be the most usable, well written, edited, illustrated, and designed module it possibly can be, and we can't wait to show you the finished product.
Work in progress. Not final.
Every spread is bullet pointed out so that Wardens don't have to read huge blocks of text to know what's in a given area. They can simply read the bullet points and bolded entries, and if players want more information, further details are in nested lists beneath each bullet point. 
Work in progress. The room starts with a quick, one sentence description of what's going on and is then followed by bullet points. Wardens can quickly scan the bullet points to give players the most relevant information, only reading further down when they have to.
Dangers (like traps or enemies) are highlighted in red and with a unique icon (!) so that you're not five minutes into exploring a room before you find out there was a gun-toting maniac in there the whole time. Additionally, the bottom of the page has icons for whether there's artificial gravity on the page, Oxygen, or light -- with icons then used on individual rooms when they differ from the area at large. 
Mothership is an ENnie award-winning (Best Game, Gen Con 2019) sci-fi horror roleplaying game that places a huge emphasis on being easy to run but difficult to beat. It uses a simple d100 roll-under system similar to Call of Cthulhu, Warhammer Fantasy Roleplay and the Basic Role Playing system. It's incredibly easy to hack, so you can meet your table's needs (increasing or decreasing the difficulty as necessary to create a fun and challenging time) without a lot of effort.
You play as one of four classes: Teamster, Android, Scientist, or Marine, and then customize that class to your liking with a branching skill tree. 
Click the image to download the character sheet!
We wanted building characters to be easy so we put all the rules for character creation right there on the character sheet. With a game this deadly it's important that players are able to get right back into the action if their character dies. And why is it so deadly? Well, aside from just taking damage (from, you know, like, a scalpel wielding void raider) your characters also accumulate Stress which builds up until something terrible happens (like oh, you know, seeing your crew mate get ripped in half by the thing that just crawled its way out of the airlock), after which you'll make a Panic Check. If you roll poorly your character could be inflicted with awful conditions ranging from chronic night terrors to permanent phobias to full on psychopathic rampages!
Trust us, it's fun.
If you want to check out the system the PDF of the Player's Survival Guide is Pay What You Want on itch.io or DriveThruRPG. Take a look and let us know what you think. We've also got a great Discord server with an awesome community full of people ready to answer questions and help out with anything you need.
 Gradient Descent is written, edited, and produced by an incredible award winning team:
Written by Luke Gearing (Fever Swamp, Broken System)
Art by Nick Tofani (Instagram, Patreon)
Edited by Jarrett Crader (Troika!, Mothership, Ultraviolet Grasslands)
Layout by Sean McCoy (Mothership, Two Rooms and a Boom)



Work in progress. Not final.




 We've got some awesome stretch goals coming up -- so keep an eye out! 
"...A master class in presenting RPG rules and settings in a very graphical, readable, and gameable way. And it just looks gorgeous." -- Gareth Branwyn, Boing Boing
"This might be my favorite role playing game other than D&D” -- The Secret Cabal Podcast
"This thing walks to the line of usability/performance art, looks down at it, and does a jig on it with its tongue hanging out waggling, while flipping the world off with both hands. It gets about as close as you can to the usability/art line." -- Bryce Lynch, Ten Foot Pole 
"Such a great example of design in RPGs... If I was gonna run a sci-fi horror game this is the only game I'd use... Strongly recommended." -- Ben Milton, Questing Beast
"It was thematically so tight and so fun. ...Really cool system. ...Definitely worth checking out!" -- Shut Up & Sit Down
"Mothership is a supremely cool sci-fi DIY zine game whose supplements really know how to create a fun module without railroading players. Designers and players alike should check it out!" -- Adam Koebel, Dungeon World
"What a great game. What an impressive achievement... I cannot say enough great things about Mothership. I want you to go buy it right now." -- Dungeons & Possums

updates.update_userinfo: Shipping is complete! Stretch goals in progress
updates.update_content:
Hey gang,

By now all of you should have received your physical and PDF copies of Gradient Descent. If you haven't, please reach out at contact@tuesdayknightgames.com and we'll get you sorted out. Next up, we're working on the Wardens Screen stretch goal and also the extra pamphlet adventure (it's a pretty sweet one). So, we'll keep you updated as to how that's going.

Hey everyone,

Hope you're all doing well going into the holidays. We have started to fulfill your kickstarter pledges! Quartermaster has already shipped US packages and international shipments are on their way to their regional distribution centers. As usual, COVID plays a huge part in this, but I'm getting word that some people in the Eastern US are already receiving their pledges.

Woo-hoo! 
I've just sent Gradient Descent off to print after two weeks of proofreading and final checking everything to make this as perfect as can possibly be. Mixam should have the printing done largely sometime late next week and then it'll be shipped to Quartermaster our fulfillment company to start packing and shipping, the end is in sight!

Hey gang,
We finished up our first round of proofreading and boy was it a big one. The biggest hassle in proofreading a Megadungeon is all the room references. Each minimap has to correspond to both the key and the overworld map, as well as any other room that references it through the module. Jarrett Crader and David Wilkie went through each map with a fine tooth comb and looked for inaccuracies in them, of which there were a couple dozen.

updates.update_userinfo: Layout, Editing, Art complete -- moving into final Proofreading
updates.update_content:
Hey gang,
As some of you may have seen in the comments, a little over a week ago I finished up the final layout for Gradient Descent and sent it over to Jarrett for editing. Jarrett did an amazing job and finished editing last week, I've spent this past week making his final changes, and now we're ready to move into final proofreading! We'll be starting that this weekend and then we'll be sending it off to print!

Hey gang!
Progress is moving along quickly now, we're on the downhill run! We're nearly to editing, sorry for the delays, but we've had a ton of playtesting reports come in and we went back through and updated some sections and maps that sorely needed it, but its pushed back our timeline a bit. I anticipate going to print in August, but we'll let you know if anything changes. We've also added about another four pages of content to help with the setup of the module and also detail more information about the Bell, which caused some delays again in layout. Sorry about the delays, but we think it'll be worth it in the end.

updates.update_userinfo: IMPORTANT Change to T-shirt Orders, Production Updates, and ENnie Awards!
updates.update_content:
Hey gang,
Hope you're all doing well. It's been a crazy few weeks. We're trucking right along still, but right up front we think we'll need to delay for about a month. Layout is about 90% done but we need a decent chunk of time to edit because the module is so complex, and my personal productivity was hit pretty hard a couple of weeks ago. That being said, we're moving along at a good clip now and I'm hoping to wrap up layout in the next week or two and then start the editing process in earnest.

campaign.story:
Yes, we have a demo booklet that has 50 pages of content in it. The good thing is, it is only a glimpse of how much you will have in Corpus Malicious!
Here is the new demo booklet for Mindabar - The City of Malice!
You can download  the demo booklets by clicking this link
Sample page of the demo booklet
By backing us now, you will help the development of Corpus Malicious. We will make this possible thanks to you! Additionally, you can take advantage of the generous pricing and additional content we have for our backers specifically. When our Stretch Goal opens, you can also pledge for our special collector’s edition which has its cover made of (synthetic) leather.
In Dungeons and Dragons, stories and adventures are often depicted in black and white. Also, evil is often seen as evil, without looking at the reasons behind it. As Dream Realm Storytellers, we believe in the power of lore for much deeper stories and campaigns. So in Corpus Malicious, we will provide a lot of information about nature, reasons, and acts of evil.
The rules of degeneration will provide gifts and curses that will add meaning to the corruption of evil.
Rotten essence makes the character more undead-like and unfeeling while providing advantages in necromancy and aspects of death.
Foul essence makes the character more fiendish while providing favors from devils and demons.
Maddening essence makes the character lose its mind to the truth of the Far Realm, but also provide the eternal insights of it.
Desecrating essence is the character’s inner, pure evilness manifested to the outside but increasing the character's means of self-preservation or evil agendas. 
In addition to the rules of degeneration, you will have rules for vampirism, lycanthropy, making sacrifices and an economy for soul trade.
You can create or become a vampire or werewolf, exploring much more depth of being one than what is given in D&D.
Sacrifices are an important aspect of evil. Both players and Dungeon Masters can use the rules for sacrifice to add both mechanics and flavor to their game.
Soul trade is a common practice of demons and devils but it is left abstract in D&D, the economy of soul trade will add vast detail for this economy.
Corpus Malicious has pages and pages of archetypes for every class in Dungeons and Dragons. The number of archetypes we have is even larger than that of the core books! Each archetype has the theme and flavors for unique, dark approaches to D&D classes. For example, you can be a dark templar, a paladin that is devoted to a dark god from the beginning. Or you can be a warlock who dominates devils and demons rather than obeying them as patrons.
Fallen Angel - Remnant
You will be able to create your character with uncommon and interesting races, which can be plot materials or quest hooks even on their own. For example, with fallen angel race you can experience what it is like to literally fall from grace, and start a new life with your lessened angelic abilities. With remnant, you can experience shades of undeath by being a character who has died at some point in life but somehow refused to pass away.
Cultist
We are designing backgrounds that are especially suitable for evil or antihero characters. For example, murderer provides the depths of a past-time, or serial murderer, with different reasons, goals, or flaws. Cultist background provides the depths of how a character joined a cult, what are the thoughts, and what are the flaws regarding the viewpoint of the cult.
There are many monsters of demon, devil, undead, abomination origins. There are also monsters of horror from folk myths and legends. Each monster has its own background that can fit multiple settings and a detailed description about its lore.
Book of Tainted Mind
Magical items are not just tools for greater success, they have their own character! Magical items in Corpus Malicious comes in various forms. All of them have a flavor and theme suitable for an aspect of evil. They have their own stories as well, which you can use as a hook or lore in your adventures or campaigns.
Spears of Vengeance - Art by Gökhan Kahraman
You will discover mysterious, eccentric, and often wicked and frightening cults with Corpus Malicious. All the cults have their methods of initiation, known agendas, secret agendas, and possible relationships.
In your campaigns, you will be able to use many villains that have unique characteristics and themes. You will also realize that even a common villain such as an orc can have much depth in it, as well as much more potential for dread.
For adding more occult, flavor, and tactics to your spellcaster characters or villains, WE HAVE 100 NEW SPELLS and RITUALS!
Delve into spells that are too wicked for respectable guilds of magic to acknowledge. You will also learn forbidden rituals that provide great rewards but take dire sacrifices.
Also for more wickedness, we have 15 NEW FEATS in new player options! AND MORE!
Mindabar is an evil setting that provides detailed lore about a cursed, cosmopolitan city. Dungeon masters can find everything they need: buildings, NPCs, inns, special days, traditions, culture, art, and even food. With all the lore, it is possible to design a campaign that takes place only in Mindabar.
The first draft of the map
The book will be softcover and around 70 pages long.
When our Mountain of Skulls $42,500 Stretch Goal passes, Skull Collector’s Edition will be available among the pledges.
By making this pledge, you will get the leather edition of the book, DM Screen, and all 5 encounter map addons. 
Here is our main artists, Özge Güngör, Muhammet Feyyaz
We are working with very talented artists from Turkey and abroad. We can say that half of the 400-page book will have beautiful illustrations. This means around 200
Corpus Malicious Cover Art by Jon Elliott
Mindabar - The City of Malice Cover Art by Ömer Tunç
You will have quality artwork for every two pages! This is a ratio that is only common for big studios.
We want to do much more with Corpus Malicious, adding dozens of new content to the book including new archetypes, monsters, items, spells, villains and more. We are even planning 2 small expansions to the Corpus lore! 
On top of all this, we have even greater plans for our last stretch goals! They will be chosen by you from a poll of alternatives.
We can make this happen with YOU! Here is our list of Stretch Goals, we will be waiting very excitedly to see them unlocked.
We will be able to continue working on Corpus Malicious and Mindabar to deliver you this great supplement!
Artwork in Corpus Malicious will become even better, with more artwork and higher quality of the arts!
We will be able to print Corpus Malicious GM Screen and 5 A2 sized Encounter Maps that you can add to your pledge!
We will add 10 more FEATS to specialize your character even more. 
We will add 5 additional BACKGROUNDS to add more variety to your character’s role play.
We will add an additional RACE with a unique flavor and suitable traits for a dark game. 
We will add 5 additional CULTS that you can use against your players or join them as a character.
You will have the special, exclusive leather-covered version of Corpus Malicious available, with the GM Screen and Dungeon add-ons in Skull Collector’s Edition pledge!
We will add 25 more MAGIC ITEMS to our book. Each item has its own story and unique method for evil. Yet be careful, some of them might have a curse on them!
We will add 10 more VILLAINS to Corpus Malicious. As a Dungeon Master, you will have an even larger pool of bosses to challenge your players!
We will add 15 additional MONSTERS to our book. These monsters are various types of demons, devils, undead, or aberrations. 
Some of them are horrific legends from real folk myths and tales.
We will add 5 more ARCHETYPES to Corpus Malicious. Each of our archetypes has a different focus on D&D classes’ themes that suit evil characters or a dark campaign
We will create the first expansion for Corpus Malicious, Tome of Forbidden Magic. The tome will have dozens of new spells and unique rituals. Moreover, we will update our chapter arts to masterpieces with a lot of detail and excellent composition.
Add-ons can be added to any reward. You can increase the pledge by the amount of your chosen Add-on when you pledge, or by adjusting the pledge amount through “Manage my pledge”. 
Add-ons can also be managed after the Campaign ends, through BackerKit survey.

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We are working with the experience and relationships we gathered from producing Svilland Campaign Setting. We can say that we passed a huge learning curve while developing the book of our previous Kickstarter campaign. Because of this, our development time can actually be shorter than what we suggest in Our Schedule!

We have printing and fulfillment companies that we work for some time now as partners. Still, we also have other alternatives if any problems occur in printing or shipping with our other partners.

We have observed considerable cost increases (when hundreds of backers considered) in shipping throughout the year, so we cannot risk providing you an exact shipping cost in the pledges. We will overcome this risk by collecting the shipping costs from you towards the end of the development. Still, the shipping costs will not be quite different from what we have listed.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

Hello wicked ones,

updates.update_userinfo: Message from Umut, Our Layout and Graphic Designer
updates.update_content:
Hello, wicked ones
We are very happy to announce to you that we have finished Corpus Malicious! We have just started to send the PDF files on DriveThruRPG. We know that you have been waiting for this update, and we can guarantee that the final product of Corpus Malicious is a book that is worth the wait.
Corpus Malicious has been a long and educational story for us. Through the development time, we got a lot of feedback, evaluated them, and reshaped some parts of the book according to them. Again, we would like to thank you for your interest and feedback, since they make us develop further and create more professional products.

updates.update_userinfo: Corpus Malicious The Codex of Evil is Done
updates.update_content:
Hello wicked ones,
We are posting this update to inform you that the Backerkit surveys are now locked. Once locked, you will still be able to make changes in your address information, but you won’t be able to change your add-ons or pledge upgrades.
Your cards will be charged on Monday. Sometimes cards get declined due to insufficient funds and often due to banks thinking the transaction as fraud. If your card gets declined, no worries, we will keep on trying to charge the declined cards once a week until shipping.

Hello wicked ones,
Many of our backers have completed their surveys, but there are still more than a hundred backers who pledged for printed books but have not completed the survey. Normally, we were going to lock Backerkit surveys today. Yet, we really do not wish our unresponded backers to lose their pledges.
So, we decided to postpone the lock order date to Saturday 11:30 AM (Pacific Time). After that time, the surveys will be locked and anyone who pledged for a physical book and missed fulfilling their survey will sadly lose their physical book pledge.

updates.update_userinfo: Last Call: Surveys Will be Locked on Saturday
updates.update_content:
Hello wicked ones,
It is nearly the end of the survey month now, and we have 3 days left until the surveys are locked. We highly recommend those who haven’t completed their surveys yet to complete them. We won’t be able to fulfill a pledge if we do not have the completed survey.
We have also sent messages through Kickstarter to our backers who haven’t completed their surveys and reminding them.
